The question of the relation of
the proposed Student Board to the
Athletic Association and the eligibility of members of the Athletic
Board for election to the new body
formed the subject of a lively discussion at the mass-meeting held
last Friday to determine the constitution of the Board.
President Fulton of the Athletic
\ssociation presided and called for
the report of the Committee appointed some time previously. This
report, as read by the chairthan of
the Committee, T. Brooke Price,
proposed the creation of a_ board
composed of the president of the
Athletic Association, the president
of the senior class, and four delegates elected by the student body
from the three upper classes. On
motion of John M. Holmes, the
election of the members was turned
over to the classes which they
should represent. By a close vote,
a motion to remove the president of
the Athletic Association from membership, ex-officio, was lost; but
Emory Niles' suggestion that other
members of the Athletic Board be
debarred from serving on the new
body was adopted.

Some discussion of changing the
apportionment of the representatives among the different classes
was filially settled by the adoption
of C. Leland Getz's motion that
the freshman and sophomore classes
have one member each, the juniors
and seniors two each, of whom the
senior president should be one, and
the president of the Athletic Association make the seventh. The
classes were instructed to elect their
members within the ensuing two
weeks, so that the Board might be
organized at once.

Items

of Interest Concerning the "Loyal
Sons," Young and Old, of
Johns Hopkins.

Joseph T. Singewald, A. B. '06,
Ph.D. '10, is practicing law in this
city.
Richard J. Biggs, Jr., a former
graduate student in English, in '01,
is now consular agent at Caracas,
Venezuela.
Dr. W. P. Mustard delivered a
lecture at Forest Park last Thursday night on "Roman Buildings in
Southern France."
Brooke Bird, ex-'09, has resigned
his position with the power company at Perryville. After a month's
rest he has undertaken his new
work under the Sewerage Commission of Baltimore.
Thomas F. Kane, Ph.D.'95, president of the University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, is now in
the East on an annual tour in quest
of professors for his University.
He was at the University for several days last week.
N. Ernest Dorsey, A. B. '93,
Ph.D. '96, is now connected with
the department of terrestrial magnetism, at Washington, D. C. He
has been appointed research associate in the Carnegie Instifution of
Washington, and his work will be
carried on in its department of terrestrial magnetism.
J. Martin Hammond, special student 'o8, who was recently connected with a New Orleans paper,
is now engaged in the lithographing
business in Philadelphia.
Rev. Whiteford L. McDowell,
'91, has been stationed for the last
two years at the Roland Park M. E.
Church.
"Billie" Haynes, ex-'12, of fame
in so many lines that we haven't
space to enumerate them all, is the
author of a series of three articles
now running in the Outing magazine. The Outing company will
also publish another book from his
versatile pen early next month. It
will be entitled "Scotch and Irish
Terriers." This is a companion
book to the "Airedale Terrier,"
which "Billie" wrote last fall ; and
in addition to these, Country Life
has accepted an article for later in
the spring.
A Dream of Springtime.
One night when 1 had indigestion,
My thoughts went roving, fancy-free;
I dreamed spring-fever epidemic
Went 'round the University:
The Dean was playing Diablo,
The boys were pitching nickles,
The. barber was serving a free lunch:
A shave, two buns, two pickles.

Dr. Greene was coaching the ball team,
"The black-list" died of jim-jams,
And I was a-swallowing ice cream
In place of Easter "exams."
Oh, 'twas only_ a dream of springtime,
It wasn't a fact at all;
But here's to the day when dreams come
true,
'And a health to Thomas R. Ball!

Alexander Pope was once called
upon to answer
the toast "The
Press." He expanded as follows:
THE PRESS.
There various news I heard of love and
strife,
Of peace and war, health, sickness,
death and life,
Of loss and gain, of famine and of store,
Of storm at sea and travel on the shore,
Of turns of fortune; changes in the State,
Of fall of favorites, prpjects of the great,
Old mismanagements, taztations new.
All neither wholly false, nor wholly true.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 18, 1912
The Technical School.

Reports from Annapolis indicate
that real progress is being made in
the agitation for a State technical
school under the direction of the
Hopkins. On Monday last, the Joint
Legislative Committee appointed to
consider the necessary appropriation, recommended that $600,0oo be
given for the building and equipment of the school, and $5o,o00
year for the maintenance. The bill
for the appropriation will he introduced first in the Senate, as soon
as the Roads Loan is out of the
way.
It is interesting to note how
strong the desire of the public is
for the establishment of a technical
school in Maryland. All the papers
are heartily in favor of it, and they
have presented in their columns the

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH
Sophomores' Elections.

THE NEWS-LETTER MAIL BAG

The sophomores held several important elections this week at a
well attended meeting Tuesday.
The following were elected to the
Hullabaloo Board:
A. L. Hammond, editor-in-chief.
Associate Editors—F. K. Leland,
S. D. White, C. A. Wells, C. E.
Porter, V. H. Bridgman and H. E.
Corner.
Business Managers — Lawrence
Getz, head; A. K. Barton, G. T. 0.
Hollyday, assistants.
The art editor will be chosen according to the quality of work submitted.
H. E. Corner was elected delegate to the student council.
The elections for captain and
manager of the class teams were:
Baseball—J. H. Rice, captain;
J. L. Dorsey, manager.
Lacrosse—W. D. Sutton, captain;
W. Everton, manager.
Tennis—W. Geissel, captain; D.
Powers, manager.

(('ontinued from page 5.)

MARCH

At the freshman class meeting
Friday, Claud I. Uhler was elected
as delegate to Student Council.
Thomas Troxall was elected
corresponding--secretary, to succeed
"Bobby" Randolph, who has left
the University.
Hutzler and . Thompson were
'elected as captains of the freshman
basket-ball team.

schedules of matches as announced
by the Tournament Committee follows:
Round i—Corner vs. Yokohama,
Davis vs. Stiebel, and Hammond vs.
Weber.

Davis vs. Corner, and Hammond
VS. Burka.

Stiebel vs. Burka, and Yokohama
vs. Hammond.
Round 4—Yokahama vs. Stiebel,
nammond vs. Corner, and Davis
vs. Burka.

Stiebel vs. Corner, and Davis vs.
Yokohaza.
Round 6—Hammond vs. Stiebel,
Nachlas vs.,Corner, and Yokohama
Vs. Burka.
Round 7—Nachlas vs. Yokohama, Hammond vs. Davis, and Burka
VS. Corner.
All matches are to be played as
soon as possible, and should be rePorted to the Tournament Committee as soon as finished. The members of the Committee are Albert
L. Hammond and B. Benedict.

Freshman Banquet in Washington.

Freshman Class Meeting.

18, 1912.

The freshman class with its honorary member, Charles Leland Getz,
held its banquet in Washington
Saturday night after a day of sightseeing.
This is the first Hopkins class to
hold its "feed" out of Baltimore,
and it will probably establish a
precedent. The reasons for going
to Washington were that a large
number of the "freshies" had never
been to the nation's capital, that
they could spend a day sociably together as a class, and that they
would be doing something original.
The novelty was so successful that
it was suggested by several -members that the 1915 class hold all its
future banquets in Washington.
The party left Baltimore on the
Washington, Baltimore and Annapolis Electric line in a special
car at one o'clock. At Washington
they split into several groups, some
going to the government buildings,
others to the zoological gardens and
some to moving pictures and lunchrooms.
In the group visiting the Capitol,
White House, Congressional Library and other buildings, was
Freshman Hseuh Wu Sun, of
China. He was greatly impressed
by the splendor and system of the
American government. This party
heard tariff debates in the House
of Representatives between Congressmen Oscar Underwood,"Nick"
Longworth and others.
At seven o'clock, the students assembled in the Red Parlor of the
New Ebbitt Hotel. A rest, songs
and (lancing consumed an hour, and
then to the banquet hall. Eight
courses of Washington's "best" appeased the freshman hunger, and
Toastmaster Claude I. Uhler led
"Our Alma Mater in Dixie Land."
The sentiment of the entire body
of migrating freshmen was expressed by Hseuh Wu Sun, who
said, when a-sked how he enjoyed
the day : "I give to it one word—
magnificent!"

BASEBALL SUPPLIES

The question of the relation of
the proposed Student Board to the
Athletic Association and the eligibility of members of the Athletic
Board for election to the new body
formed the subject of a lively discussion at the mass-meeting held
last Friday to determine the constitution of the Board.
President Fulton of the Athletic
\ssociation presided and called for
the report of the Committee appointed some time previously. This
report, as read by the chairthan of
the Committee, T. Brooke Price,
proposed the creation of a_ board
composed of the president of the
Athletic Association, the president
of the senior class, and four delegates elected by the student body
from the three upper classes. On
motion of John M. Holmes, the
election of the members was turned
over to the classes which they
should represent. By a close vote,
a motion to remove the president of
the Athletic Association from membership, ex-officio, was lost; but
Emory Niles' suggestion that other
members of the Athletic Board be
debarred from serving on the new
body was adopted.

Joseph T. Singewald, A. B. '06,
Ph.D. '10, is practicing law in this
city.
Richard J. Biggs, Jr., a former
graduate student in English, in '01,
is now consular agent at Caracas,
Venezuela.
Dr. W. P. Mustard delivered a
lecture at Forest Park last Thursday night on "Roman Buildings in
Southern France."
Brooke Bird, ex-'09, has resigned
his position with the power company at Perryville. After a month's
rest he has undertaken his new
work under the Sewerage Commission of Baltimore.
Thomas F. Kane, Ph.D.'95, president of the University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, is now in
the East on an annual tour in quest
of professors for his University.
He was at the University for several days last week.
N. Ernest Dorsey, A. B. '93,
Ph.D. '96, is now connected with
the department of terrestrial magnetism, at Washington, D. C. He
has been appointed research associate in the Carnegie Instifution of
Washington, and his work will be
carried on in its department of terrestrial magnetism.
J. Martin Hammond, special student 'o8, who was recently connected with a New Orleans paper,
is now engaged in the lithographing
business in Philadelphia.
Rev. Whiteford L. McDowell,
'91, has been stationed for the last
two years at the Roland Park M. E.
Church.
"Billie" Haynes, ex-'12, of fame
in so many lines that we haven't
space to enumerate them all, is the
author of a series of three articles
now running in the Outing magazine. The Outing company will
also publish another book from his
versatile pen early next month. It
will be entitled "Scotch and Irish
Terriers." This is a companion
book to the "Airedale Terrier,"
which "Billie" wrote last fall ; and
in addition to these, Country Life
has accepted an article for later in
the spring.
A Dream of Springtime.
One night when 1 had indigestion,
My thoughts went roving, fancy-free;
I dreamed spring-fever epidemic
Went 'round the University:
The Dean was playing Diablo,
The boys were pitching nickles,
The. barber was serving a free lunch:
A shave, two buns, two pickles.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 18, 1912
The Technical School.

Reports from Annapolis indicate
that real progress is being made in
the agitation for a State technical
school under the direction of the
Hopkins. On Monday last, the Joint
Legislative Committee appointed to
consider the necessary appropriation, recommended that $600,0oo be
given for the building and equipment of the school, and $5o,o00
year for the maintenance. The bill
for the appropriation will he introduced first in the Senate, as soon
as the Roads Loan is out of the
way.
It is interesting to note how
strong the desire of the public is
for the establishment of a technical
school in Maryland. All the papers
are heartily in favor of it, and they
have presented in their columns the
views on the subject of many prominent and well informed men. Every
one of them felt that the Commonwealth would derive great benefit
from such an institution, which
wctuld develop men who might
otherwise lose the chance into potent forces for the upbuilding of
the material prosperity of Maryland. These same men felt that
the Hopkins would be the best place
for the school. A careful examination of the correspondence columns
of the city papers for the last few
weeks shows many letters in favor
of Johns Hopkins, and only one
against—that by a man who had
the basis of his argument sadly
mixed.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH
Sophomores' Elections.

THE NEWS-LETTER MAIL BAG

The sophomores held several important elections this week at a
well attended meeting Tuesday.
The following were elected to the
Hullabaloo Board:
A. L. Hammond, editor-in-chief.
Associate Editors—F. K. Leland,
S. D. White, C. A. Wells, C. E.
Porter, V. H. Bridgman and H. E.
Corner.
Business Managers — Lawrence
Getz, head; A. K. Barton, G. T. 0.
Hollyday, assistants.
The art editor will be chosen according to the quality of work submitted.
H. E. Corner was elected delegate to the student council.
The elections for captain and
manager of the class teams were:
Baseball—J. H. Rice, captain;
J. L. Dorsey, manager.
Lacrosse—W. D. Sutton, captain;
W. Everton, manager.
Tennis—W. Geissel, captain; D.
Powers, manager.

Freshman Banquet in Washington.

Freshman Class Meeting.

18, 1912.

The freshman class with its honorary member, Charles Leland Getz,
held its banquet in Washington
Saturday night after a day of sightseeing.
This is the first Hopkins class to
hold its "feed" out of Baltimore,
and it will probably establish a
precedent. The reasons for going
to Washington were that a large
number of the "freshies" had never
been to the nation's capital, that
they could spend a day sociably together as a class, and that they
would be doing something original.
The novelty was so successful that
it was suggested by several -members that the 1915 class hold all its
future banquets in Washington.
The party left Baltimore on the
Washington, Baltimore and Annapolis Electric line in a special
car at one o'clock. At Washington
they split into several groups, some
going to the government buildings,
others to the zoological gardens and
some to moving pictures and lunchrooms.
In the group visiting the Capitol,
White House, Congressional Library and other buildings, was
Freshman Hseuh Wu Sun, of
China. He was greatly impressed
by the splendor and system of the
American government. This party
heard tariff debates in the House
of Representatives between Congressmen Oscar Underwood,"Nick"
Longworth and others.
At seven o'clock, the students assembled in the Red Parlor of the
New Ebbitt Hotel. A rest, songs
and (lancing consumed an hour, and
then to the banquet hall. Eight
courses of Washington's "best" appeased the freshman hunger, and
Toastmaster Claude I. Uhler led
"Our Alma Mater in Dixie Land."
The sentiment of the entire body
of migrating freshmen was expressed by Hseuh Wu Sun, who
said, when a-sked how he enjoyed
the day : "I give to it one word—
magnificent!"
